title: @Any Rioter: So I can pay people to boost me via Dynamic Q?
body:
So long as they're not logging into my account and boosting it first hand, I'm allowed to pay a challenger (or multiple if I see fit) to log into a lower ranked account of theirs(s), group with me, and carry all my matches for me until I am also challenger?

Apparently the defense for Rioter's allowing boosting through DQ (and streamers now using it as a form to gain more income from their viewers, i.e: paying to get carried) is because of a loophole of "Well technically boosting is logging into the boostee's account so any other form of it is okay."

Since as of now Rioter's are allowing popular streamers to charge people for playing with them in order to get boosted, I'm making the assumption this is 100% allowed now, right? 

FYI: I have no intention to do this, I think it's piis poor and a cheap tactic to climb, but apparently it's allowed if myself or anyone wanted to do so. 
I was under the impression that money + climbing ranks without doing it via your own merit =  against ToS.

replies.body: What prevented this in the old ranked system?

> [{quoted}](name=ApocaIypse Meow,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=jF9BzpbN,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2016-04-13T20:19:20.592+0000)
>
> What prevented this in the old ranked system?

As far as non-team ranked went, you were limited to a duo at most. Ostensibly limiting a team to just one 1 high elo in disguise who may or may not be able to consistently carry his boostee and 3 bad teammates. Obviously could do it since we see high elo climb out of low elo on new characters all the time, but it could be more difficult. 

Now you can have a boostee + 4 boosters, or other combinations like 2 boostees and 3 boosters, allowing for a faster and more consistent climb, since the randomness of the other players on team can be controlled. Faster and more consistent makes it more attractive to both sides and more lucrative to boosters.

{{champion:267}} Im pretty sure the act of tanking their elo to get to a place where they can queue with someone much lower is against the rules somewhere but as far as I understand and have seen, this is happening a lot. I ran into a pair of higher elos doing this. Fresh accounts, lost all 10 of their provisional games on purpose (I happened to be in one of those losses and have been watching them since) and then right when they hit that bronze they started triple queing with another player in bronze who had 100+ games there and within another 10 or so games, that player was silver and the duo boosters are back to tanking their elo back into bronze to do it with more people.

I would like to know Riot's actual stance on this in particular.

It's against the rules. However, the issue is that it's significantly easier to get away with. Paying money for an in-game advantage that isn't an official thing is punishable in every single multiplayer game today. (A couple examples of official advantages would be WoW's level boost or RuneScape's bonds that you can sell for in-game currency.)
Technically, yes. As I said, it's much easier to get away with now and a lot easier to pull off considering you can have 5 people in a premade now.
yup there is no way to enforce this.  this is why i want soloQ
